thread.title: 10 worst S&P 500 stocks led by Caterpillar decline
thread.title_full: 10 worst S&P 500 stocks led by Caterpillar decline - MarketWatch

author: Philip van Doorn
title: 10 worst S&P 500 stocks led by Caterpillar decline
text:
The decline in China’s stock market has been alarming, and slowing manufacturing also is scaring investors, but the clearest sign of the international economic slowdown is weak commodity prices.
Copper for December delivery HGZ5, +0.13% was flat at $2.30 a pound Thursday, but several companies involved in the mining business were leading the S&P 500 Index to a decline of 1.1%.
Read: Why this market is stuck in a ‘nervous zone’
Caterpillar Inc. was hit hardest, down 7% after the company said it was “building for a stronger future” by eliminating 4,000 to 5,000 jobs by the end of 2016, with total cuts of up to 10,000 employees through 2018.
The drop in copper prices over the past 12 months shows just how terrible the business environment is for miners and companies that supply them:
FactSet The five-year chart for copper is even worse:
FactSet Here are today’s 10 weakest S&P 500 stocks:
Company Ticker Industry Price decline - Thursday Price decline from 12-month high Caterpillar Inc. CAT, -5.74% Trucks/ Construction/ Farm Machinery -7.0% -38.7% United Rentals Inc. URI, -3.70% Equipment Rental -4.6% -49.3% Parker-Hannifin Corp. PH, -3.52% Industrial Machinery -4.6% -27.7% Deere & Co. DE, -3.35% Trucks/ Construction/ Farm Machinery -4.0% -23.3% Tenet Healthcare Corp. THC, -4.30% Hospital/ Nursing Management -3.4% -29.4% FMC Corp. FMC, -3.55% Agricultural Chemicals -3.4% -45.6% Vulcan Materials Co. VMC, -3.85% Construction Materials -3.3% -8.5% Delphi Automotive PLC DLPH, -2.97% Auto Parts: OEM -3.2% -19.6% CF Industries Holdings Inc. CF, -2.58% Agricultural Chemicals -3.2% -32.9% Lam Research Corp. LRCX, -1.73% Electronic Production Equipment -3.1% -26.9% Source: FactSet Caterpillar lowered its sales outlook for 2015 to $48 billion from $49 billion and said it expected sales to decline 5% during 2016.
Read: BMW shares skid on report of higher-than-allowed emissions
With sales declining for three straight years so far, Caterpillar CEO Doug Oberhelman said the company was facing “a convergence of challenging marketplace conditions” in mining and energy. By the company’s planned actions, it’s clear that Oberhelman doesn’t expect a recovery for precious metals or oil prices any time soon.
